verses.text: When all the nation had finished crossing over the Jordan, the LORD spoke to Joshua,
verses.comment: The word 'nation' is rendered for the Hebrew 'people,' signifying the entire community of Israel.

verses.text: "Take twelve men from the people, one man from each tribe,
verses.comment: Twelve men reflect the unity and representation of the twelve tribes of Israel.

verses.text: and command them, saying, 'Take twelve stones from here out of the middle of the Jordan, from the spot where the priests' feet stood firm, and carry them over with you, and lay them down in the place where you will stay tonight.'"
verses.comment: The 'middle of the Jordan' points to the exact location of the miraculous crossing.

verses.text: So Joshua called the twelve men whom he had appointed from the children of Israel, one man from each tribe.
verses.comment: Affirms the earlier selection of the twelve representatives.

verses.text: And Joshua said to them, "Cross over before the ark of the LORD your God into the middle of the Jordan, and each of you take up a stone upon his shoulder, according to the number of the tribes of the children of Israel,
verses.comment: Carrying stones on the shoulder emphasizes their size and the solemnity of the act.

verses.text: so this will be a sign among you. When your children ask in time to come, 'What do these stones mean to you?'
verses.comment: The Hebrew term for 'sign' (oth) signifies a memorial or marker.

verses.text: then you shall answer them, 'Because the waters of the Jordan were cut off before the ark of the covenant of the LORD; when it passed over the Jordan, the waters of the Jordan were cut off.' So these stones shall be for a memorial to the children of Israel forever."
verses.comment: The phrase 'cut off' directly reflects the miraculous stopping of the river.

verses.text: So the children of Israel did as Joshua commanded, and took up twelve stones out of the middle of the Jordan, just as the LORD had spoken to Joshua, according to the number of the tribes of the children of Israel. And they carried them over to the place where they lodged, and set them down there.
verses.comment: Highlights obedience to Joshua and continuity with God's command.

verses.text: Joshua also set up twelve stones in the middle of the Jordan, in the place where the feet of the priests who carried the ark of the covenant stood. And they are there to this day.
verses.comment: Potential textual note: 'to this day' signals the memorial’s continued presence at the time of writing.

verses.text: For the priests who carried the ark stood in the middle of the Jordan until everything the LORD commanded Joshua to tell the people was finished, according to what Moses had commanded Joshua. Then the people hurried and crossed over.
verses.comment: Cross-reference to Moses anticipates the continuity of leadership and obedience.

verses.text: And when all the people had finished crossing over, the ark of the LORD and the priests crossed over before the people.
verses.comment: Shows the priests and ark as the last to cross, highlighting God's presence and order.

verses.text: And the sons of Reuben and the sons of Gad and half the tribe of Manasseh crossed over armed in front of the Israelites, just as Moses had spoken to them.
verses.comment: Armed crossing remembered as fulfillment of their earlier vow.

verses.text: About forty thousand armed men, ready for war, passed over before the LORD for battle, to the plains of Jericho.
verses.comment: “Ready for war” renders the Hebrew 'prepared for battle.'

verses.text: On that day the LORD exalted Joshua in the sight of all Israel, and they respected him just as they had respected Moses all the days of his life.
verses.comment: ‘Exalted’ signals public confirmation of Joshua as God’s chosen leader.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Joshua,
verses.comment: Simple narrative marker displays ongoing divine instruction.

verses.text: "Command the priests who carry the ark of the testimony to come up out of the Jordan."
verses.comment: ‘Ark of the testimony’ is a common synonym for ‘ark of the covenant.’

verses.text: So Joshua commanded the priests, saying, "Come up out of the Jordan."
verses.comment: Direct obedience to the LORD’s command.

verses.text: And when the priests who carried the ark of the covenant of the LORD came up out of the middle of the Jordan, and the soles of the priests' feet were raised up onto dry ground, the waters of the Jordan returned to their place and overflowed all its banks as before.
verses.comment: ‘Overflowed all its banks’ ties to the earlier description in ch. 3.

verses.text: On the tenth day of the first month, the people went up from the Jordan and camped at Gilgal, on the east side of Jericho.
verses.comment: ‘Tenth day of the first month’ corresponds with the Passover preparation.

verses.text: And those twelve stones which they took out of the Jordan, Joshua set up at Gilgal.
verses.comment: Gilgal becomes a site of remembrance for the crossing.

verses.text: He said to the people of Israel, "When your children ask their fathers in time to come, 'What do these stones mean?'
verses.comment: Almost identical repetition, stressing generational instruction.

verses.text: then you shall let your children know, saying, 'Israel crossed over this Jordan on dry ground.'
verses.comment: Mirroring earlier wording of the divine sign.

verses.text: "For the LORD your God dried up the waters of the Jordan before you until you crossed over, as the LORD your God did to the Red Sea, which He dried up before us until we had crossed over.
verses.comment: Draws a theological parallel between the crossing of the Red Sea and the Jordan.

verses.text: so that all the peoples of the earth may know the hand of the LORD, that it is mighty, so that you may fear the LORD your God forever."
verses.comment: ‘Hand of the LORD’ is an idiom for God’s power and action.
